Stem: Life cycles of cockroach and housefly shown. Which statement correctly describes these two life cycles?
Image/Diagram Description: Comparative life cycle diagrams for cockroach (incomplete metamorphosis) and housefly (complete metamorphosis) (1218x690).
Choices: A) Both have exactly three stages, B) Both begin with egg and end with adult, C) In both the young looks similar to adult, D) Both include a pupa stage
Scenario Justification: Rich visual data showing two different life cycles side by side. Students must compare and identify the correct description.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students compare two visual life cycle diagrams and evaluate which statement accurately describes both.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of different metamorphosis types and identifying what is common to both. Deep DCI engagement.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying common pattern across different life cycles).
Key Recommendation: Strong comparative analysis question with real visual data. One of the best G3.16 items.

Stem: Which statement correctly describes a unique feature in the life cycle of insects like butterflies?
Choices: A) They undergo metamorphosis changing from larva to chrysalis to adult, B) They are born live from their mother, C) They have a simple life cycle of birth growth reproduction and death, D) They lay eggs in water where young develop
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks about butterfly metamorphosis as isolated fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of complete metamorphosis. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide unfamiliar insect life cycle data and ask students to classify the metamorphosis type.

Stem: Which correctly describes the sequence in a flowering plant's life cycle?
Choices: A) Seed produces flowers first then roots, B) Adult develops from fruit then produces flowers, C) Seed develops into seedling then adult plant that produces flowers fruit and seeds, D) Seedling transforms into seed then grows
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure sequence recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Ordering memorized sequence.
DCI Justification: Tests plant life cycle sequence knowledge. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide plant growth observation data and ask students to identify stages from evidence.

Stem: A class makes a chart showing students with different colored eyes. Which claim is best supported by the data?
Image/Diagram Description: Eye color data chart: Brown=14, Blue=10.
Choices: A) All students inherit brown eyes, B) Blue-eyed students will eventually have brown eyes, C) Students can inherit different eye color traits from parents, D) Eye color is not inherited
Scenario Justification: Real classroom data about trait variation. Students must use data to support a claim.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking' and 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — students evaluate which claim the data supports.
DCI Justification: Requires using data evidence to evaluate claims about inheritance. Goes beyond recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (variation in eye color is a pattern in the data).
Key Recommendation: Strong data-driven question. Students evaluate claims using real classroom data.

Stem: Which animal characteristic is NOT inherited from parents?
Choices: A) A budgerigar's black-and-white wing pattern, B) A dog's ability to respond to its name, C) A mandrill's colorful facial markings, D) A lion's round ear shape
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Identifying the learned behavior from a list.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Classification task.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of inherited vs. learned traits. Recall with minor reasoning.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on animal traits across generations and ask students to classify each as inherited or learned with evidence.

Stem: A student notices she and her mother have naturally curly hair while her friend got curly hair from a salon treatment. Which statement correctly identifies these traits?
Choices: A) Acquired because environmental factors, B) Acquired because it's a physical characteristic, C) Inherited because passed from parent, D) Inherited because she combs it every day
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario comparing natural curly hair (inherited) with salon curly hair (acquired). Natural controlled comparison.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students distinguish inherited from acquired traits using a real-world comparison.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the difference between inherited and environmentally acquired traits. Goes beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (genetics → natural curly hair vs. salon treatment → artificial curly hair).
Key Recommendation: Good comparison scenario. Elevate by providing data on multiple traits across families showing both inherited and environmental variation.

Stem: During winter caribou face challenging conditions. Which best describes an adaptation that helps caribou survive in cold?
Choices: A) Change color to white to blend with snow, B) Hibernate in underground burrows, C) Store food in hidden caches, D) Thick fur provides insulation against cold
Scenario Justification: Brief environmental context but no specific data or observation.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Selecting the correct adaptation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structural adaptations for cold environments. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on fur thickness and body temperature in different conditions and ask students to analyze the pattern.

Stem: A scientist finds seashell and pine cone fossils at the same place. What does this suggest about the environment long ago?
Choices: A) Environment changed over time from water to land, B) Pine trees used to grow underwater, C) Fossils came from two different continents, D) Seashells were blown into the forest by wind
Scenario Justification: Brief fossil discovery scenario. Students reason about past environmental change from evidence.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations from Evidence' — reasoning from fossil evidence to environmental conclusions.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that fossils indicate past environments. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Stability and Change (environment changed over time).
Key Recommendation: Add more fossil details (layer information, specific organisms) and ask students to construct a detailed timeline.

Stem: Which trait of an elephant functions as an adaptation that helps it survive?
Choices: A) Gray skin for decoration, B) Trunk for gathering food and water, C) Large ears for attracting mates, D) Tusks for displaying age
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure identification of functional adaptation.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structure-function relationship. Recall level.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function implicitly but not required for answer.
Key Recommendation: Provide comparative data on elephant traits across different habitats and ask students to explain how each adaptation provides advantage.

Stem: Which ecosystem is characterized by minimal rainfall thin nutrient-poor soil and water conservation adaptations?
Choices: A) Desert, B) Tropical rain forest, C) Temperate deciduous forest, D) Tide pool
Scenario Justification: Multi-clue description but task is matching characteristics to a known ecosystem.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Classification/matching task.
DCI Justification: Tests ecosystem identification from characteristics. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (characteristic patterns define ecosystems).
Key Recommendation: Provide actual climate data for multiple ecosystems and ask students to compare and classify.

Stem: A meteorologist gathered July temperature data for Washington DC Los Angeles Cape Town and Sydney. Which conclusion is best supported by the data?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing July temperatures and precipitation for 4 cities in different hemispheres (1436x700).
Choices: A) Washington DC has higher temps but lower precip than LA, B) Southern Hemisphere cities have lower temps in July than Northern Hemisphere cities, C) Chance of precipitation is directly related to temperature, D) LA and Sydney have similar temperature ranges despite different hemispheres
Scenario Justification: Rich real-world climate data table with 4 cities across hemispheres. Students must analyze multi-variable data to identify the supported conclusion.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' at high level — students must evaluate multiple data points across cities and hemispheres to determine which conclusion the data supports. Requires evaluating all four claims against data.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of seasonal differences between hemispheres using real data. Deep reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (hemispheric temperature patterns in July) and Cause and Effect (Earth's tilt causes reversed seasons).
Key Recommendation: Excellent data-driven question. Multi-city hemispheric comparison with real data. Approaches Doing Science level.

Stem: Temperature data table shown for a week. Which statement best describes the temperatures shown?
Image/Diagram Description: Weekly temperature data table with high and low temperatures (1200x474).
Choices: A) Mediterranean climate with hot dry summers, B) Temperatures consistently decrease Monday to Friday, C) Daily temperature range was 15°F each day, D) Monday had the greatest difference between high and low temperatures
Scenario Justification: Real weather data table for a week. Students must analyze daily temperature patterns.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must calculate daily temperature ranges and compare across days to determine which statement is accurate.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of weather data analysis and temperature ranges. Goes beyond recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying the day with the greatest temperature variation).
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question. Students must calculate and compare temperature ranges.

Stem: Coastal town shore washed away during storm. People built concrete seawall. How will the seawall help protect the town?
Image/Diagram Description: Before and after images of coast with seawall (734x592 and 712x592).
Choices: A) Seawall will become a path people can walk along, B) Seawall will stop water from moving onto the land, C) Seawall will increase sand brought by waves, D) Seawall will increase the number of waves
Scenario Justification: Real-world engineering scenario with visual evidence (before/after images). Students evaluate the seawall's function.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating how an engineering solution addresses the problem. Visual evidence supports reasoning.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how engineering solutions address weather-related hazards. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (seawall blocks water movement → protects land) and Structure and Function.
Key Recommendation: Good visual scenario. Elevate by providing data on water levels and damage before/after seawall installation.

Stem: A soccer ball is resting on the ground. You lightly tap it forward. Which statement best describes the force?
Choices: A) Push because you move ball away from foot, B) Pull because you move ball toward you, C) Both push and pull, D) No force required
Scenario Justification: Simple everyday scenario. Force identification.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Force identification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of push forces. Basic application.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide force measurement data from different kicks and ask students to analyze the relationship between force and distance.

Stem: A student pushing a ball to the right at constant speed. Which force acts in the opposite direction?
Choices: A) Gravity pulling downward, B) Friction between floor and ball, C) Floor's upward support force, D) Ball's own forward force
Scenario Justification: Scenario about forces during constant-speed motion. Requires understanding of friction.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — identifying the opposing force requires reasoning about what maintains constant speed.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of friction as the opposing force during constant-speed motion. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (friction opposes motion → constant speed when balanced with push).
Key Recommendation: Provide data from friction experiments on different surfaces and ask students to predict and explain results.

Stem: Diagram shows four balls with different masses. Student pushes each with same force on same surface. Which ball rolls shortest distance?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of 4 balls with labeled masses (1112x472).
Choices: A) Ball 1, B) Ball 2, C) Ball 3, D) Ball 4
Scenario Justification: Visual data showing balls with different masses. Students must apply force-mass relationship using the diagram.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students use mass data from the diagram to predict which ball rolls shortest.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how mass affects motion when force is constant. Application with data.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (greater mass → less movement for same force).
Key Recommendation: Good data-driven question. Elevate by providing experimental data for different masses and asking students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Which is an example of a situation caused by static electricity?
Choices: A) Metal spoon pushing food, B) Child sliding down plastic slide, C) Rock falling due to gravity, D) Balloon sticking to wall after rubbing against hair
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Identifying an example of static electricity from a list.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall/identification.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of static electricity examples. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide experimental data on different materials rubbed together and their effects. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Student rolls metal ball on table with magnets at four locations (W-Z). Ball rolls to magnet Z and stops. Which must be true about magnet Z?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing rolling ball and 4 magnets at different positions around table (956x402).
Choices: A) Z is weaker than W and Y but stronger than X, B) Z is weaker than W X and Y, C) Z is stronger than W and Y but weaker than X, D) Z is stronger than W X and Y
Scenario Justification: Rich experimental scenario with visual data showing ball trajectory and magnet positions. Students must reason about relative magnet strength from ball behavior.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students analyze the ball's trajectory past multiple magnets to determine relative strength. Multi-step reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of magnetic force and distance to reason about why the ball passed other magnets but stopped at Z.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (strongest magnet stops the ball) and Patterns (ball trajectory reveals relative magnet strengths).
Key Recommendation: Excellent spatial reasoning question. Students must analyze trajectory data to determine relative magnet strength.

Stem: Which object can stick paper to a metal door and still work the same way after being taken off and put back many times?
Choices: A) sticky tape, B) ruler, C) paper clip, D) magnet
Scenario Justification: Practical scenario about reusable attachment. Basic application.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Identification task.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnet properties (reusable attraction to metal). Application level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Replace with engineering design problem requiring magnet-based solution evaluation.

Stem: Homeowner in hurricane region needs shutters that are quick to secure reusable and operable from inside. Which type best meets requirements?
Choices: A) Plywood — low cost but effort to install, B) Storm Panels — inexpensive but manual attachment, C) Roll-Down — higher cost but easy to operate from inside durable, D) Fabric Screens — lightweight but less durable
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario with specific criteria and constraints. Each option includes trade-off information.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — students evaluate multiple solutions against multiple criteria with explicit trade-offs. Strong practice engagement.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of engineering design trade-offs for weather hazard protection.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (design features → meeting criteria).
Key Recommendation: Good engineering scenario with trade-offs. One of the better G3 engineering items. Elevate by adding cost and installation time data.

Stem: Why are flowers an important part of many plants' life cycles?
Choices: A) Help plants stay tall and strong, B) Help plants make seeds, C) Help plants grow roots, D) Help plants make leaves
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of flower function.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of flower function. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from pollination experiments and ask students to explain the relationship between flowers and seed production.

Stem: A student plants two seeds. One grows healthy; the other never grows because it didn't get enough sunlight air or water. Which part of the life cycle did not happen for the second seed?
Choices: A) Reproduction, B) Pollination, C) Fertilization, D) Germination
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario with controlled comparison (two seeds with different conditions). Students identify the failed life cycle stage.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — connecting the lack of resources to a specific life cycle failure.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of germination requirements. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (lack of resources → failed germination).
Key Recommendation: Provide seed germination data under different conditions and ask students to identify which factors are most important.
